desc:
Immutable representation of the most recent interaction with an asynchronous computation.

See also:

  • StreamBuilder, which builds itself based on a snapshot from interacting with a Stream.
  • FutureBuilder, which builds itself based on a snapshot from interacting with a Future.
name: widgets.AsyncSnapshot

methods.desc:
Returns a snapshot like this one, but in the specified state.

The data and error fields persist unmodified, even if the new state is ConnectionState.none.
methods.example:
Implementation

AsyncSnapshot<T> inState(ConnectionState state) => AsyncSnapshot<T>._(state, data, error);
methods.name: inState

methods.desc: Returns a string representation of this object.
methods.name: toString

props.desc: Current state of connection to the asynchronous computation.
props.name: connectionState

props.desc:
The latest error object received by the asynchronous computation.

If this is non-null, hasError will be true.

If data is not null, this will be null.
props.name: error

props.desc:
Returns whether this snapshot contains a non-null data value.

This can be false even when the asynchronous computation has completed successfully, if the computation did not return a non-null value. For example, a Future<void> will complete with the null value even if it completes successfully.
props.example:
Implementation

bool get hasData => data != null;
props.name: hasData

props.desc:
Returns whether this snapshot contains a non-null error value.

This is always true if the asynchronous computation's last result was failure.
props.example:
Implementation

bool get hasError => error != null;
props.name: hasError

props.desc:
The hash code for this object.

A hash code is a single integer which represents the state of the object that affects operator == comparisons.

All objects have hash codes. The default hash code represents only the identity of the object, the same way as the default operator == implementation only considers objects equal if they are identical (see identityHashCode).

If operator == is overridden to use the object state instead, the hash code must also be changed to represent that state.

Hash codes must be the same for objects that are equal to each other according to operator ==. The hash code of an object should only change if the object changes in a way that affects equality. There are no further requirements for the hash codes. They need not be consistent between executions of the same program and there are no distribution guarantees.

Objects that are not equal are allowed to have the same hash code, it is even technically allowed that all instances have the same hash code, but if clashes happen too often, it may reduce the efficiency of hash-based data structures like HashSet or HashMap.

If a subclass overrides hashCode, it should override the operator == operator as well to maintain consistency.
props.example:
Implementation

@override
int get hashCode => hashValues(connectionState, data, error);
props.name: hashCode
